snippet: After two studies of low-calorie diets among monkeys reached opposing conclusions, one team has struck back, asserting that the other study was in error because its control group was also fed a lean diet.
abstract: Research group at the University of Wisconsin publishes study in the journal Nature Communications that refutes study done by rival research group about restricted diets in rhesus monkeys, asserting that that study was in error; Wisconsin group and group at the National Institute on Aging laboratory in Baltimore have come to different conclusions about whether diet meager in calories could increase longevity.
lead_paragraph: After two studies of low-calorie diets among monkeys reached opposing conclusions, one team has struck back, asserting that the other study was in error because its control group was also fed a lean diet.

headline.main: Diet’s Link to Longevity: After 2 Studies Diverge, a Search for Consensus
headline.print_headline: Diet’s Link to Longevity: After 2 Studies Diverge, a Search for Consensus
